description: Dive into "Whispers of Love in Kumamoto" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Whispers of Love in Kumamoto

places.generalDescription: Kat≈ç Shrine is a historic Shinto shrine dedicated to Kiyomasa Kat≈ç, a prominent warlord of the Warring States period who played a significant role in building Kumamoto Castle and establishing the city's foundation. It is quite rare to find a shrine in Japan that venerates an actual historical figure, highlighting the close relationship between Kiyomasa and Kumamoto.

sources.snippet: Kato Shrine is where Kato Kiyomasa, the local feudal lord of the 14th and 15th centuries, is enshrined. Originally built within Kumamoto Castle, the shrine was moved to the Kyomachi area of Kumamoto in 1874, then in 1962, moved to its current location. After visiting the castle, be sure to wander through this beautiful shrine.
sources.shortName: 17 Fun Things to Do in Kumamoto - Places to Go, Local Food & Sightseeing Points of Interest

sources.snippet: Kato Shrine is dedicated to Lord Kato Kiyomasa, the builder of Kumamoto Castle. After a couple relocations, the shrine is now located within the castle grounds and is a great spot to take photos of the keeps. Kato Shrine also offers a great view of Uto Yagura, one of the few original wooden structures of the castle.
sources.shortName: Getting In & Around - Visit Kumamoto City

places.name: Kat≈ç Shrine

reviews.text:
We took a walk here to enjoy the calm and quiet atmosphere. Laid down our prays for the coming year and also, had an amazing view of the Kumamoto Castle.

The shrine is about a 10-minute walk from Kumamoto Castle, well worth a visit!

Located near the castle, this shrine is a peaceful and historically significant site, dedicated to Kat≈ç Kiyomasa, the samurai lord who built Kumamoto Castle in the early 17th century.

It's a quiet place to take a break from the crowds and enjoy a bit of history and culture. The atmosphere is serene, and the shrine grounds are well maintained. A good place to visit if you're already exploring the castle area.

a very wonderful shrine. vibrant color, beautiful trees, also offer a very special view of kumamoto castle. if you are luckier, you could observe the weeding ceremony being hold upstairs for the japanese. the tori gate and the tree is gorgeous

places.generalDescription: Suizenji Jojuen Garden is a serene and picturesque Japanese landscape garden located in Kumamoto. It was originally constructed by the renowned Hosokawa family during the 17th century and has since been opened to the public as a tranquil park. The garden features meticulously designed miniature landmarks, including small rolling hills and a replica of Mount Fuji. Visitors can also enjoy attractions such as a tea house, a large pond, traditional Noh theater performances, and occasional horse archery tournaments.

sources.snippet: Like many of Japan‚Äôs warrior class, the feudal lords of Kumamoto Castle enjoyed taking pleasure in the finer things in life. This love is highlighted at a spring-fed pond about 10 minutes‚Äô drive from the castle, which was sculpted into a traditional strolling garden during the castle‚Äôs heyday. Known today as Suizenji Jojuen Garden, the grounds remain a beautiful place for a stroll.
sources.shortName: Explore Japan's cultural experiences on Kyushu

sources.snippet: Suizenji Jojuen Garden is a tranquil Japanese garden built in 1632 by Tadatoshi Hosokawa, the first lord of the Kumamoto domain. At first, it housed Suizenji Temple, but when the latter was relocated and a tea house replaced it, the garden became a retreat for the Hosokawa family members. Suizenji Jojuen is laid out so that it reproduces in miniature form the 53 post stations of the Tokaido (the road that connected Tokyo and Kyoto during the Edo Period,) including a small version of Mt. Fuji and a little Lake Biwa.
sources.shortName: 25 Best Things to Do in Kumamoto, One of Japan's Most Picturesque Regions

sources.snippet: About 400 years ago, the people of Kumamoto harnessed the raw beauty of the land when they created the incredible Suizenji Garden. The careful construction of the garden‚Äôs pond, trees, stones and hills are representatives of key landmarks along the 53 Stations of the Tokaido route in Japan. In the park there is even a small, pointy replica of Mount Fuji.
sources.shortName: Kumamoto Japan ‚Äì All You Need To Know To Enjoy Your Trip

sources.snippet: This traditional garden takes about 15 minutes by tram from downtown Kumamoto and is a quiet oasis among the bustle of the city. Be sure to get off at Suizenji Park and not Shinsuizenji Station. After getting off the tram, head north down the diagonal street until you see a big torii gate and a shopping street that leads to the park entrance.
sources.shortName: Getting In & Around - Visit Kumamoto City

sources.snippet: It was originally built inside Kyoto‚Äôs imperial palace during the Edo era, then was transported to its current location in 1912. Visitors can enjoy matcha with traditional sweets while sitting on tatami mats and gazing over the serene tsukiyama (hill garden) landscape. There‚Äôs also outside seating available.
sources.shortName: Inredible things to do in Kumamoto, Japan

sources.snippet: Unlike the hustle and bustle of major economic centers, Kumamoto is a place where travelers turn to when they need to immerse themselves in nature. Among the landscapes in this city, Suizenji Jojuen is one of the most transformed destinations with unique architecture and deep historical and cultural values.
sources.shortName: 12 Famous Tourist Destinations in Kumamoto, Japan

sources.snippet: A highlight of Kumamoto for tourists and a romantic spot is Suizenji Jojuen Garden. This traditional garden has miniatures of many Japanese landmarks, including Mount Fuji. You can walk around the entire garden in an hour or two (depending on how long you stop to look at the monuments).
sources.shortName: Great Places for a Date in Kumamoto

sources.snippet: Along with Kumamoto Castle, Suizenji Jojuen Garden (sometimes called Suizenji Park) is one of the main tourist spots in Kumamoto City. The carefully manicured gardens occupy an important place in Kumamoto‚Äôs history and speak volumes of Kumamoto‚Äôs unique samurai culture.

places.name: Suizenji Jojuen

reviews.text: Peaceful garden if you come in the morning to beat the tourists. Accessible by tram and only a few minutes walk from the tram station. You can buy koi or pigeon food for 200 yen for small bag or 500 yen one big bag. The mini Mt Fuji is kind of not that impressive but the garden is still nice. There are vending machines and a few public restrooms. We spent about 80 minutes here feeding the koi and pigeons, so expect to spend between 30 minutes to maybe 2 hours here if you enjoy just sitting down and taking in the surroundings. Beware of mosquitoes in the summer because there is standing water.

A beautiful and well-maintained Japanese garden, offering a peaceful escape from the city's hustle and bustle. The landscape is carefully designed, featuring a large pond, traditional tea houses, and a miniature representation of the Tokaido road, including a small Mt. Fuji. The garden reflects the beauty of Japanese aesthetics, with seasonal flowers adding to its charm.

The entrance fee is 400 yen as of March 2025.

A great spot to take a relaxing stroll, enjoy and admire the harmony of nature.

Enjoy üòéüôèüßòüßò‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

I went here to relax after a long day. It's a quiet park with lots of benches around the lake. There aren't many people around. There's a shrine inside and some small torii gates. The lake has a lot of fish as well. I saw many cherry trees, so this park must be even more beautiful during cherry blossom season.

Entrance fee for adult is 400yen.

places.address: 8-1 Suizenji Koen, Chuo Ward, Kumamoto, 862-0956, Japan

places.generalDescription: Kumamoto Hotel Castle is an upscale accommodation with stylish rooms, four dining options, a wedding chapel, and a club lounge. Located in Kumamoto Prefecture, the region experiences varying climates due to its diverse topography. The area around Aso has an average annual temperature of 59 to 62 degrees with significant seasonal variations. Visitors can explore the iconic Kumamoto Castle, one of Japan's largest and most renowned castle complexes.

sources.snippet: Kumamoto Hotel Castle has elegant interiors with a more classic feel. Pick this place for a romantic trip ‚Äî the suites are generously appointed ‚Äî or for a family holiday. Kumamoto Castle is minutes away on foot, and there are four excellent restaurants.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Kumamoto, Japan

places.name: Kumamoto Hotel Castle

reviews.text: I love how old school this hotel is. We stayed in 2 x castle view rooms, which were completely worth it. Rooms were quiet and comfortable. Parking was 1000¬•. Great location. Helpful and attentive staff.

The staffs provide us an excellent service since the car pick-up , door man to the receptionist.

The hotel is in an old fashion but newly renovated.

Breakfast is good enough but not variety of choices.

We booked the castle view room but the windows are not clean enough to enjoy the view.

Amazing value for money. Rooms are big for Japan. Beds are comfy. Service is great. We appreciated that we could park our car right in front of the hotel for no charge. Location is great, right in front of the Kumamoto castle, which is one of the greatest in Japan. On the downside, the place is a little bit tired and you may find the overall atmosphere a bit gloomy. But for the price, it is a bargain. Many food options if you walk East or North. Recommend to pay a little more to have a room facing the castle.

places.generalDescription: Sakura-yu - Yamaga Onsen Motoyu is a reconstructed public bathhouse featuring hot spring pools housed in a traditional Edo period wooden structure. Originally built as a vacation residence for Hosokawa Tadatoshi, the lord of the Higo region, this resort has been welcoming visitors since 1870. Over the years, it has become an iconic and social focal point for the people of Yamaga. The Edo-style building exudes charm and offers clean facilities.

sources.snippet: Yamaga Onsen Sakura-yu is one of the oldest hot springs in Japan, with its origins dating back about 370 years. The resort was built as a vacation home for Hosokawa Tadatoshi, lord of the Higo region. The hot spring was opened to the public in 1870 and in use for about a hundred years, becoming a beloved symbol and social hub for the citizens of Yamaga.
sources.shortName: 17 Fun Things to Do in Kumamoto - Places to Go, Local Food & Sightseeing Points of Interest

places.name: Sakura-yu - Yamaga Onsen Motoyu

reviews.text:
Oh my gosh! This is truly awesome. Spacious, clean, a high ceiling and excellent hotspring water in a beautiful period building. The indoor baths are segregated. There is also a round Dragon Bath with a very nice drawing of a dragon on its high ceiling. The Dragon Bath is open from 9 am to 5 pm and it reminds one of the royal baths of long ago. Fabulous!

The lockers are FOC. The lockers in the dressing area are at ¬•10 and refundable. The charges for the toiletries are fair. Bringing your own toiletries or purchasing from the Onsen is a choice we can make and I would surely exercise the choice and enjoy what the onsen has to offer.

We have been to onsen across Japan, spending at least 2 months each year (Yes, we are Onsen enthusiasts) and this Onsen is one that Japan and Kyushu can be proud of.

The biggest onsen I've visited in Japan so far. The high ceiling makes it feel very spacious. When I visited in the evening there were many locals happily chatting away in the bath, making it more relaxing (some onsens are so deadly silent it's almost uncomfortable).

Such a beautiful Edo style building. The facilities are nice and clean. And the water is simple alkaline which leaves your body relaxed and healed.
You can purchase single-use shampoo, body soap, towels etc. at the front desk. Otherwise take your own. Very affordable price, adults are only ¬•350. You can use the lockers in the locker room for ¬•10.

Adequate parking and you can also park the plaza next door  for up to 2 hours.

places.generalDescription: Izumi Shrine is a reconstructed Shinto temple and shrine that was damaged during World War II. The park surrounding it also features a Noh theater, a guest room from the Kyoto Imperial Palace, and a garden adorned with cherry blossoms, pine trees, ponds, stones, and an artificial hill resembling Mt. Visitors can partake in worship, festivals, and ceremonies at the shrine.

sources.snippet: To the north of the garden is the Izumi Shrine, dating from 1878, the year after the city of Kumamoto was burned down in the Satsuma Rebellion. It is said that the rebels may have used the miniature Mt. Fuji to mount an artillery battery in the attack. The pine tree here is said to have grown from a bonsai cultivated by the first-generation Hosokawa lord, Tadatoshi.

places.name: Izumi Shrine

reviews.text: Located within the serene Suizenji Jojuen Garden, Izumi Shrine is a peaceful Shinto shrine dedicated to the Hosokawa family, the feudal lords of Kumamoto. This sacred spot is not only a place of worship but also a cultural and historical landmark, offering visitors a glimpse into the region's rich heritage and spiritual traditions.
Izumi Jinja ‚ÄúComing out of Water‚Äù  Shrine in Suizenji Jojuen Garden.  The Fensi is great facing a gorgeous lake   A good symbol for us.

Izumi Shrine is a serene and historic shrine located within Suizenji Jojuen Garden in Kumamoto. Founded in 1878 by former retainers of the Kumamoto domain, the shrine was established to pray for the reconstruction of the city after the Satsuma Rebellion. It enshrines the spirits of past lords of the Higo domain, including Hosokawa Fujitaka (Yusai) and his wife Gracia.

Visitors to the shrine can enjoy the beautiful scenery of the garden, take part in seasonal events, and explore the cultural sites within the area. Praying at Izumi Shrine is believed to bring good health, prosperity in business, and academic success.

places.address: 8-1 Suizenji Koen, Chuo Ward, Kumamoto, 862-0956, Japan

places.generalDescription: Hotel Nikko Kumamoto is a luxurious accommodation located in the heart of Kumamoto city, offering warm and comfortable rooms with views of the famous Kumamoto Castle. The hotel features 4 restaurants, a bakery, and a cocktail bar, providing guests with various dining options. With its convenient location near Torichosuji Train Station and JR Kumamoto Train Station, as well as free wired internet access in rooms, it offers both comfort and accessibility for travelers.

sources.snippet: Hotel Nikko Kumamoto is just moments from the acclaimed City Museum of Contemporary Art. Swish, contemporary rooms offer panoramic city views, big cosy beds and flat-screen TVs. Dine on French, Japanese or Cantonese fare after days of exploring.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Kumamoto, Japan

places.name: Hotel Nikko Kumamoto

reviews.text: Great downtown hotel with close proximity to mall and nearby attractions.  Great view of Kumamoto caste.  Hotel service people were awesome and accommodating.   Rooms were very clean.  In-house resteraunts were great.  Laundy service was top-notch and very prompt.  Highly recommend!

A very good hotel, well located with many shops and restaurants nearby. The design is elegant, with a beautiful reception area that creates a welcoming atmosphere.

The rooms are very clean, with comfortable beds ensuring a restful stay. I had a quiet room, which was a big plus.

The staff are friendly and professional, always ready to assist. While the hotel lacks a gym and a swimming pool, its excellent amenities and overall quality make it the best choice in Kumamoto city.

Enjoy üòé

I had a wonderful and memorable stay here. My room was large, clean and comfortable with a nice view. The breakfast buffet was good and the restaurant staff were lovely. There are attractions and shopping close by. I did find the dinner options in the hotel a bit limited (it seemed some restaurants were temporarily closed) but it wasn't a problem for me as you can find other restaurants around. A huge thank you to all the staff (including front desk, concierge, housekeeping and restaurant) as this was my first time in Japan and the staff were so welcoming and helpful, I very much appreciated it.

places.generalDescription: Unganzenji Temple is a serene Buddhist temple nestled in lush greenery, established by a renowned Zen monk within a mountainside cave. The temple houses the famous Reigando Cave, where Miyamoto Musashi, an iconic Japanese swordsman, penned his martial arts treatise "The Book of Five Rings" during the last years of his life. Visitors can explore the cave and even drink from the spring next to the modern temple building that dates back 50 years.

sources.snippet: Another idea for an active date is to visit Unganzenji Temple, where you can explore Reigando Cave. This will be particularly popular with anyone interested in samurai because it was here that the ronin Miyamoto Musashi spent the last months of his life writing The Book of Five Rings and meditating. There are suggestions that he is also buried here.
sources.shortName: Great Places for a Date in Kumamoto

places.name: Unganzenji Temple

reviews.text: Neat little temple. It was 25 minutes and $40yen by taxi... worth it considering the buses don't run often. Took 45 mins, maybe to tour thro the whole temple area, and see the view of the farm fields next to the temple grounds. Worth it. Just make sure to have a number to call a taxi when your done.

This is the temple in front of the Matsumoto Musashi cave   it is an amazing place with a very deep spiritual feeling if you can go on a weekday it is not very busy just sit and listen to the world and imagine a man writing his book 400 years ago very special

This place is known for where the Miyamoto Musashi spent his last days and where he wrote the Book of Five Rings. The cave is outside of Kumamoto and quite difficult to reach with public transportation. I spent 5'000¬• for the taxi. The temple and cave are nice and the place is a must visit if you know Miyamoto Musashi. It was pretty empty. I luckily met an American (Chris) who was kind enough to take me back to Kumamoto Station! If you read this Chris, many thanks again!!! If you ever come to Zurich, let me know.

places.address: 589 Matsuomachi Hirayama, Nishi Ward, ÁÜäÊú¨Â∏ÇË•øÂå∫ Kumamoto 861-5282, Japan

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Kumamoto, The New Hotel Kumamoto offers a delightful blend of comfort and convenience. Just a short drive from iconic landmarks like Kumamoto Castle and the bustling Amu Plaza, this hotel is perfectly situated for exploring the city. Guests can enjoy complimentary Wi-Fi throughout their stay, making it easy to share travel experiences online.

sources.snippet: Rooms are simply furnished, some with chabudai dining tables. There's a buffet restaurant & sultry lobby bar, plus special space for private dining. Rates are reasonable and it's close to public transport, so a great choice for easy exploring.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Kumamoto, Japan

places.name: ONE STATION HOTEL KUMAMOTO

reviews.text: Nice and clean room. Good service with free luggage storage. Great location: very close to the train station and bus/tram stops within 3-5 minutes walking distance. Long distance bus to Fukuoka is just few steps on right side at the bus stop #7! (If you want to have a cost effective travel with no need to transfer in the middle, this is best way to Fukuoka.)

The location is convenient. No need to cross any intersection from the station to the hotel.

However, when checking out, the staff I met was kind of in a hurry and throwing questions with a very firm tone, while there was no one waiting in the line. It was totally unexpected as I didn't meet any other receptionist who was with this attitude in the whole area. The other staff at the hotel I talked with were polite with their speaking.

Also, the room is advertised to be newly renovated one month ago, and I paid one-third of the extra price to get a renovated room instead of a non-renovated room, I found that the cushions inside the room have a large portion of visible stains, and the carpet is very dirty. The bed seems to be clean.

The hotel has undergone renovation, but it still retains a bit of an 80's vibe (e.g. a bar/lounge in the lobby with live music in the evening and metal keys to access the rooms). The breakfast buffet offers good quality and a wide selection.

The room is clean with run-of-the-mill, utilitarian furniture and furnishings. There is free VOD. Hotel policy stipulates that the room will be cleaned free of charge every 3 days. Otherwise, there is a charge of JPÔø•1,000/day for bed makeup & room cleaning. There is no charge for garbage collection, towel replacement.

The bus stop for the airport limousine is literally outside the front entrance. The hotel is also conveniently located near in the JR Kumamoto Station, streetcar stop and Amu Plaza Mall (a 2-min walk). Hence, there are a lot of dining, shopping and transportation options.

places.address: 1 Chome-13-1 Kasuga, Nishi Ward, Kumamoto, 860-0047, Japan

places.generalDescription: Matsuya Honkan is a refined hotel with modest yet elegant rooms, offering top-notch dining options and exclusive indoor bathhouses. The cuisine, particularly the banquet dishes and the unique iron plate horse meat, comes highly recommended. Guests praise the spacious and immaculate private rooms, perfect for special occasions. The hotel's first-class customer service adds to the overall comfort of the stay.

sources.snippet: Set next to Suizenji Park, this ryokan is just outside downtown Kumamoto. Warmly-decorated Japanese-Western style rooms feature tatami corners, plus there are two private baths. Delicious seasonal fare is served in the restaurant and there's a stylish bar.
sources.shortName: Best places to stay in Kumamoto, Japan

places.name: Matsuya Honkan

reviews.text: Nice hotel and the service is really good. It's near the heart of the city with Free parking.
Very thoughtful service. We stayed 2 nights, they ensure we have different experiences by rotating the dining rooms and osen. They even have infant setup at these places too!
Super nice local hotel with super service in a quiet neighborhood.

places.address: 23-1 Suizenji Koen, Chuo Ward, Kumamoto, 862-0956, Japan
